review:
[i]You are an office clerk. Deliver the message. Run fast! to the Queen of Ice. Run, run! Or you'll have to start the game again. [/i]

NO THING. Run fast. Turn left, turn light. Deliver the message to the Queen of Ice. All those words in my head. I feel I am that office clerk. This is a fantastic and challenging maze runner with a touch of a platformer game. NO THING is also an addictive game, maybe one of the most addictive games aI ever played in years. Difficult and you need to be fast minded or you loose. I do not recommend to play it if you suffer headaches. Those changing and blowing neon colors, fast, fast,fast!

What did I love from No Thing? The background story of the game. But also, the shining colors, the music, the art. I loved the art, is just amazing. Minimalistic, with a touch of a not so retro future. I think every decade has a different concept of the future. The game is placed in 1994, and the future is so minimal, so colorful and so monotone at the same time.

Totalitarian regime? Maybe sounds like 1894. What do you think? Just follow the story.

I can't forget the music, the music is an electronic constant in my head right now, a retro techno of the 80's. Great for the art concept in general. This is more than a platformer game, really, more than that. 

No Thing is a quite a conceptual game, one of few ones. Actually, I don't remember the last time I played a game like this one.

The gameplay is simple: use right and left keys to navigate and run. Deliver the message, discover the story behind. Think fast and maybe you'll pass the game. Use the physics on your side or you'll have to start again and again and again. Happened to me. A lot of times actually.

And I don't play it if you suffer headaches. 

I recommend the game, not only for the difficulty, also the story behind and the concept in general. 

My shoes are shining...

author: {'steamid': '76561197991140811', 'num_games_owned': 5786, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 789, 'last_played': 1463481141}
review:
[b]NO THING is an oddly addictive runner game with a great soundtrack and a brilliant story...if you care to listen close enough[/b]

The idea of NO THING is very simple: you are a simple office clerk with a message you must deliver to the Ice Queen. The gameplay consists of you navigating levels with nothing more than your left and right keys. Though it sounds easy at first, NO THING is anything but. 
You start on level one which is an easy introduction of what is to come. You must follow the path in front of you turning left and right when needed. There is a voice speaking to you as you play, telling you things, some which make sense and some which don't (not right away anyway) and a rather awesome soundtrack playing. You'll see images whilst you play that'll change depending on what's being said. You should spend your time playing NO THING listening and looking very carefully.

The levels progressively get harder, not just from level one to level two, but whilst you are actually playing them. Platforms will move, appear and disappear. Graphics will flicker, glitch (intentional) and change colour. Images will change, enlarge, shrink and move through platforms. Everything that happens is there to test your focus and concentration; [b]this is not a game for those who suffer from motion sickness or anything similar.[/b] NO THING is all about your perception of things and requires you not only to evaluate your surroundings quickly but to also ignore all of the background distraction. Platforms come in different sizes, some being thin and some wider. There are others which are slanted, some which don't properly connect and some which are slightly off centre. You must be alert at all times whilst playing because even clicking half a second too late could be the difference between winning a level and starting all over again. As you run you gain speed continually though I've not yet worked out if this is linked to the amount of turns you take or how long you've been running for. Your speed can work for you or against you, often being helpful for flying from one platform to others that would have been out of reach at a lower speed, but it also makes things a lot harder as your reaction speed has to increase with it. You can find red blocks in certain places to reduce your speed if things start getting a little out of control.
Falling from a platform doesn't always mean death though. Many levels weave in and out of each other and are on different heights so if you can react quick enough you can find yourself at another part of the level and just continue running.
Your paths will grow as you progress in the stage and some of them require you to repeatedly run the same path multiple times before something new opens. Often you'll find this will happen quickly and throw you off guard. You can also take different paths, though they'll all eventually lead to the same place, after all, choice is just an illusion in a totalitarian world. 

But the enjoyment of NO THING doesn't just come from the gameplay itself, what really grips you is the story and the way you experience it. Everything, from the dialogue to the music to the images, it just keeps you wanting to play, to find out more, to reach the end. You'll spend the game trying to work out what's going on in this world, with you, and the voice but slowly you'll piece things together bit by bit. 
I found NO THING to be oddly relaxing. When the gameplay wasn't frustrating because i'd failed so many times, the pressing right and left at the right time combined with the soundtrack was oddly calming. At some points when you find your rhythm the game flows perfectly and the levels are long enough that when they aren't too hard and you know the route you need to take, it just works. 

There are only two negative things I can really find about the game, the first is the lack of some kind of a free runner mode. Given the games intense difficulty it would be enjoyable to have endless (or large) levels to practice on so you don't have to continuously repeat a level you're stuck on until you beat it. This is directly link to my second issue which is the fact that the game can feel repetitive at times if you cannot complete a level. There was one particular part where I was reaching 99% and missing the last turn meaning I had to replay the entire level over and over hearing the same dialogue. Though the voice-over is what makes the game so good, hearing it for the 12th time after doing the same bit of a very long level 12 times is rage-inducing. I think a checkpoint system would help but in the same breath I think it'd take something away from the game. The grinding and repetitiveness is a good mirror of life in a totalitarian regime. 

[b]I don't know if it was the intention of NO THING to be a dark mirror of reality but I think it does it perfectly. I've never found a game for $4 that's as addictive as this and I really can't recommend this game enough, the experience has been amazing so far. Though difficult at times, the challenge is worth it. How hard can it be, after all, you are just the simplest office clerk. You have one message and you know what you should do. [/b]

认真的讲，这个游戏就是视觉与听觉的双重精神污染。
整个游戏只用四个键，空格开始，ESC退出，左右键或者AD键调整方向。游戏内容就是在10个相当简单的地图里曲曲折折的路径上左转右转。[b]红方块减速，蓝方块加速。[/b]尽管机制极其简单，操作还是相当难的。朋友们第七关基本都卡了一两小时以上。
有一个声音，一直在絮絮叨叨大喘气地念着奇怪的打油诗。剧情很诡异，死来死去中多少也思考了人生。音乐很High，好听，但是听多了会有些焦躁。
画面简单，但是一直变色很恼火。尤其是红色粉色，简直瞎眼。

不过这些都不重要，这游戏真的有毒。一玩就停不下来了，死来死去还想再来再来再来。通关以后的雀跃感，也是一般游戏很难提供的。

通关时间一般在5到10小时吧，不过也可能永远卡在第七关。

推荐觉得自己操作很好或者反应很快的人士来挑战一下。

review:
NO THING is an atmospheric runner game where you turn left and right while a computer voice directs you and tells you about the bleak expressionist dreamscape you inhabit.
I enjoy this game a lot, but it's a matter of taste. (You have to tolerate repetition, enjoy vague sad stories, and be resistant to motion sickness.)
First off, it's very inexpensive.
If you like cryptic surreal media like OFF, Yume Nikki or Twin Peaks, you will feel at home here.
The narration is depressing, evocative and mysterious. The narrator talks about isolation and tedium and occasionally gives away bits and pieces about your role in the world.
The main sources of difficulty are long levels and the unintuitive camera perspective. Once you get used to it, it's still very fun. The gameplay is reflex-based and feels kind of like Super Hexagon.
The level design gets hostile, arguably downright cheap from level 4 on, with trial&error and leaps of faith.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090981961', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1540082043}
review:
This is a seemingly very simple game, however I think it goes deeper than that. I actually managed to get past the first two levels and the dialogue was the most interesting thing I have yet to hear. It's like a book that you have to read over and over to really understand the meaning. It's like Moby Dick (perhaps not AS complex) or As I Lay Dying by William Faulkner. At first it seems like it's all nonsense with seemingly poor sentence structure, awkward phrasing but then you realize it's like that for a reason, and since the arcade style game is actually challenging, it forces you to restart and really listen to what it is saying. 

****-SPOILERS-**** sort of...

The game talks about you, a supposed "simplest office clerk" and the third level especially talks about people in your ear and it tells you to think two times implying (what I think would be) that you think twice before speaking and that you're supposed to listen to what "they" tell you. It does say after all that it is set in a totalitarian regime. 

It gives off an almost "what's the point" sort of feel, as it also talks about you the "simplest office clerk" working 8 hours and sleeping 8 hours watching tv for 8 hours and things of those sorts, a routine that is mundane and what seems pointless. You having an office job that you work for 8 hours for, to bring bread to the table, only to be stuck in routine and do nothing in your spare time but something ordinary such as watching TV. 

Life loses its meaning as it also talks about all those pointless interactions with people you have on a daily basis, one line in the game went along the lines of 'they hear you, but they don't really care about you or what you have to say' because to them you're just another "simplest office clerk". Emphasis on "simplest". They could have just said "office clerk" but no, the simplest was added, and I think that was just to put more emphasis on the whole concept that maybe this really all is pointless, working 8 hours a day, and sleeping 8 hours with people telling you what to do in your ear and you having to think twice about what to say because you're in a totaliatrian regime.  

ANOTHER line that I really found interesting went along the lines of "hoping for happiness" after you do everything that they tell you to do. But I mean really, what happiness can you achieve when all you've done and will ever do is be a simple office clerk. It really (I think) focuses on the mundane aspects of life and puts a big emphasis on the whole "what's the point ordeal" and the repeating and following orders like a machine day after day. 

Play level 3 and you'll get EXACTLY what I'm trying to convey. It's a really fantastic game. It doesn't need to be complex to get its point across, and I love these sorts of games where it really makes you think, yet it's so simple. Like Papers, Please. Maybe I read too much into this, but if you make it to the third level, and really listen to the dialogue, even in level two, you can hopefully see what I'm talking about. 

Oh, another thing. What helps me pass levels is when you're turning, wait until half of the next platform horizontal to you is past your screen before you press to switch directions. I found it helped me with timing, and gave me a bit of reference as to when to turn. 

ALL IN ALL, GREAT GAME.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001258363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1460821132}
review:
This is a very simple game. Press left and right to stay on track until end the stage. The game gets faster, and most of the challenge comes from muscle memory and timing. Each stage pretty much is 4-5 minutes long, but you'll replay them over and over to learn them without many mistakes. Might seem just artsy, but is actually challenging and fun to master.

While the visuals are pretty unique retro-minimalistic and works on its favor, it also works against the gameplay. The game changes color after certain number of inputs, and going from soft colors to suddenly a bright neon red can and will blind you while you try to stay focus. This can be a literal pain since you have to repeat stages until you beat them, leading to your eyes feel like bleeding after long sessions. It surely can be a dangerous game for people with epilepsy. Migraine being a feature sounds to me more like devs knowing about the issue and just roll with it, but i really hope they add an option to tone down the colors or a monochrome mode.

I really wanna complete this game and dig out its curious plot. But i've spent enough days with my vision on fire.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189725279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1631390081}
review:
No Thing is a weird blend of the traditional infinite runner genre, vaporwave aesthetic, the slight nausea of big airtime akin to a surfing mod in an FPS game, and visual disorientation. For a game with only two buttons it is surprisingly deep, both in execution potential and theorycrafting optimal routes; should I take this cube now? Next lap? Never? Players can tailor their choices to match their skill levels and try to complete this surprisingly difficult game.

What's also exciting about No Thing is the speedrunning possibilities. Given the technically optional nature of many of the blocks, the varying level completion requirements, and the opportunities to deviate from the intended course, you have a lot of unique ways for players to approach the challenges and try to finish the game as fast as possible. It's also a punishing game for a speedrunner; dying late on a level like 7 or 10 will set you back multiple minutes, meaning that there will be fairly big gaps between runs with 0 deaths and those with even a single death.

I would recommend this to most people who enjoy a unique challenge in their games. Level 7, for example, reminded me of the frustration I experienced in trying to complete Veni Vidi Vici in VVVVVV for the first time. The game lacks in depth of gameplay elements so if you're looking for something with a conceptually broad scope then you'd best look elsewhere. Additionally, while streaming the game I had a viewer experience some mild motion sickness. If you're prone to a motion sickness response from games, stay away.

Overall, this game is super satisfying and I definitely got more than my money's worth with the cheap price point. I plan to stream more of this game, and now that I've completed a run I'll be attempting speedruns of it as well. I encourage others to challenge themselves to do the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202473004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1460262586}
review:
Eu não sei nem por onde começar. Eu não terminei o jogo. Eu não vou terminar o jogo. Nunca. Nunca termino jogos assim, e ainda assim os amo, pelo tempo  que passo tentando terminá-los, e pelas tantas mil vezes que eu costumo abrir o jogo, após dias sem jogar, pensando "Hoje vai, é hoje que termino aquele level!", apenas para morrer aos 97%, fechar o jogo e achar que nunca mais vou abrí-lo, só para voltar a jogá-lo no dia seguinte.

NO THING é bizarro, mas de uma maneira (estranhamente) boa. Basicamente, é um jogo do estilo "runner", um filho de "FOTONICA" e "Velocibox". Lembra muito o primeiro em seu gameplay, você não aperta nenhum botão para correr, a personagem está sempre correndo. E quanto mais você aguenta, mais rápido a personagem corre. Você apenas aperta as teclas direcionais para fazer as curvas. Lembra o segundo na dificuldade dos obstáculos, e a mecânica de movimento é um pouco parecida, pelo menos na sensação.

Ele diz ter uma história, igualmente bizarra. Comecei a prestar atenção nela no começo, algo sobre você ter que enviar uma mensagem à Rainha, um monte de frases soltas sobre diversos temas, algumas esparsas sem nenhum sentido aparente. Meio filosófico, meio político, inteiramente bizarro. Mas não dá pra prestar atenção na história por muito tempo, depois o jogo fica tão difícil que se você não focar 100% no que está fazendo, você não vai longe.

E é na dificuldade que NO THING tem o seu ponto forte. Como jogos do estilo, eles são feitos para te tirar do sério. E NO THING faz isso de maneira maestral. O primeiro nível é plano, horizontal, sem muitas surpresas. Mas no segundo ele te apresenta a verticalidade, e é aí que a coisa complica. Ele também não tem um caminho só, se você enquanto estiver no ar após pular de uma plataforma, e puder tanto continuar reto ou virar à esquerda, desde que o caminho tenha continuidade, você pode, e isso contará no seu progresso. Você acumula progresso apenas por correr, não importa a direção, até se você, de alguma maneira, seguir a "contra-mão".

Alguns caminhos, inclusive, são sem saída. E é aí que o jogo começa a testar sua memória. Você lembrará que aquele caminho leva à morte, mesmo tendo passado por ele várias vezes? É difícil. Me vi morrendo várias vezes assim, mesmo confiante de que conhecia o mapa com as minhas mãos.

O visual é lindo, todo monocromático com cores que se alternam. Faces bizarras, algumas de faces conhecidas aparecem aleatoriamente no ar, assim como alguns objetos. Surreal. A trilha sonora é ótima, lembra bandas do começo da música eletrônica como Kraftwerk, e a narração em voz robótica reforça essa ideia.

Resumindo, jogo dificílimo, para quem gosta de desafiados. Divertido, bonito e a um bom preço. Recomendadíssimo.

[h1][b]Prós:[/b][/h1]

- Atmosfera surrealista e retro-futurista 
- Ótima trilha sonora de música eletrônica, lembra Kraftwerk
- Bom preço, entrega bastante conteúdo pro seu valor
- Curva de aprendizado difícil de dominar
- Bastante desafiador, fazendo jus aos clássicos do gênero

[h1][b]Contras:[/b][/h1]

- É difícil entender a progressão de cada level, já que você não é punido por seguir caminhos diferentes, ele te deixa bem livre nesse aspecto, o que é um pouco ruim em um jogo tão objetivo

[h1][b]Nota final:[/b][/h1]

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198069489033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1495473074}
review:
Absolutely wonderful endless runner with an interesting story on alienation. The gameplay and graphics also heavily complement the story: the colourful overlays switching, changing graphics and tight, difficult gameplay really give the feeling of being lost, confused and tense, matching the story of isolation and alienation. The story is very difficult to follow since if you pay attention to it you'll most likely die. However this again adds to the atmosphere of confusion and alienation. Additionally the difficulty of the game allows the story to be easier to follow: as you play and die (a lot) you hear the same narration again and again, slowly picking it up in an almost subliminal manner which also helps to add to the bizarre, confused sensation the game gives you.
Absolutely incredible game, great, tight, difficult gameplay, great simplistic, poppy soundtrack, the graphics, though extremely simple really do an excellent job for the game. Heartily recommended.

review:
Video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x-XznHMqSvw


Textual summary:
A textual summary will never compare to a full video. Take a look at the video for the best possible impression.

So, Can i recommend this title? No.
Do i hate it? Also... No.

My problem with this game isn't it's very simple endless runner gameplay. It's also not the simple graphics that appear to hang around in the sky. 

My main problem is the very tight field of view, coupled with the pixelated, color-tastic psychedelic overlays. They are literally migraine inducing.
So yes, the game is cheap as dirt, and credit where due: The music is Fantastic, even if it does get repetitive on the 999th try for a level. also, the narrator and tightness of the (simple) controls are spot on.

But none of that matters, when i'm physically unable to keep playing due to migraines, and that's NO THING to joke about.

review:
A really weird but great game that requires the player to go left/ right at the right time or risk falling off the area and having to restart. It can get very difficult and frustrating as it gets faster and there is very little you can do to correct yourself if you go wrong. 

Levels get progressively harder as you get further into the game (level 7 gave me more trouble than bloodborne. Evil Indie Games is a literal game description btw) with more difficult challenges.  I died so many times on the first area alone, one at 99% complete -_- Music is really great and fits the psychadelic kinda style of the visuals. The story is so weird but interesting too in a way.

Will update as I play more but 10/10, would die at 99% area complete again.
